section-block.rac_essential-question: What is it like where we live?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Maricruz Hernández Álvarez and illustrated by Carolina Farias
section-block.rac_book_summary: Ceci is sad about the loss of her pet turtle, Macario. Grandma remembers how they honored their loved ones where she grew up in Mexico. Ceci’s friends and neighbors come together to make an ofrenda.

section-block.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Use Ee and Ff Alphabet Cards.
section-block.rac_body-text: E is for elephant. I spy an elephant. Who can show me what I spy? Continue for both sides of the cards.
Sing to the tune of “Are You Sleeping?” “We’ll go for a walk; we’ll go for a walk. Yes, we will, Yes, we will. We will see the people; We will see the buildings; Yes, we will.”

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Ofrenda. The book was written by Maricruz Hernández Álvarez. It was illustrated by Carolina Farias. Can you find the letters E and F in the title?
Pablo loves to read about real people like this girl and her grandma. He also likes to notice where stories take place.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. After, we will try to answer it together. Ready?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What do you see in Ceci’s neighborhood?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer the questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: I’ll move my hand from left to right and from top to bottom as I read
this first sentence. Grandma and Ceci are on their way to the park in their neighborhood. What places do Grandma and Ceci see?
Look at Ceci’s face. How does Ceci feel? How do you know she is thinking of her turtle? (MB)
What does Grandma tell Ceci about ofrendas?
This park is a busy place in the neighborhood. What would you do if you visited this park?
Ceci and Grandma are at the ofrenda with a picture of Macario. How do you know that Ceci is no longer sad? (MB)
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What do you see in Ceci’s neighborhood?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, using Equity Sticks, choose two or three children to share their responses.
Possible responses:
Write and read aloud short sentences about what people see in a neighborhood. Give children drawing paper and have them draw pictures of what they might see in a neighborhood.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What kinds of stores do you see in Ceci’s town?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: For children who don’t speak English at home, school may be their first regular experience outside their community and culture. Ofrenda offers the opportunity to foster confidence and peer-acceptance. Invite Spanish speakers to explain words like chocolatito (page 20) and mijita (page 25). They can also talk about the illustrations.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder:Persist in Tasks
section-block.rac_body-text: Point out that it takes hard work to make an ofrenda. Ceci and her grandma had lots of things to do. Remind children that when we work hard and don’t give up, we are persisting. Say, I wanted to learn how to play a new game, so I tried and tried and tried. I persisted. When I learned it I felt proud. Ask children to offer examples of when they persisted. (MB)

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to think about the Mind Builder and see how Ceci and her grandma work hard and persist so they can finally make the ofrenda for everyone to share. (MB)
Clifford loves reading stories about real people who persist and work hard toward a goal.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.
Read aloud the book and the Day 2 prompts.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does Ceci imagine she sees in the cloud? (MB)
Grandma takes Ceci for a walk, gives her treats, and tells her a funny story. Even though Grandma is trying, how do you know she is not making Ceci happy? (MB)
How many friends come to help?
What do Ceci’s friends want to help Ceci’s grandma create? Where do they want to make it?
Grandma had said to bring pictures and food for the ofrenda. Why does Ceci think she is ready to make the ofrenda?
Besides Grandma and Ceci, who is working hard toward the goal of making the ofrenda? What are people doing to help? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Assign pairs and give each pair an easy puzzle to finish. When completed, provide another puzzle that will pose a challenge. Encourage children as they work, offering hints as needed. After completion, ask partners which puzzle was more fun. Compliment children on persisting and explain that they should be proud of themselves for finishing the harder puzzle. (MB)
Ask children to tell about things they do at home that can be hard to do. Discuss what happens when they persist. Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about their experiences.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Persistence is an essential skill in school and life. Growth Mindset is the idea that the more we struggle to learn new things, the more our brain grows. To teach persistence, compliment effort and hard work with comments such as, “I can see you worked hard on this,” or “I’m glad you didn’t give up!” (Zimmerman, 1981.)

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_3: Role of the Author and Illustrator
section-block.rac_body-text: Show the Big Book cover and elicit that the author and illustrator work together to tell the story. Discuss each one’s role.
Show Alphabet Cards for Elephant and Fish. Invite children to complete each sentence: “Egg begins with the same letter as _____.” Continue with food, escalator, and fox.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to revisit the book Ofrenda, by Maricruz Hernández Álvarez. The author wrote the words to tell the story. The illustrator drew the pictures.
Pablo is excited to reread this book. He likes to read the author’s words and look at the illustrator’s pictures. (MB)
Think about this question as we reread today:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What do you see that lets you know this is a city?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Read-Aloud: Focus on the Role of Author and Illustrator
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer question.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Where does the author tell us Grandma and Ceci are going? What do you see in the pictures?
Look at the picture of this busy street! Can you tell me some of the ways people get from place to place in this city?
Look closely at the park. Are there any picture clues that tell us that this park in a city?
What words does the author use to tell us where Grandma and Ceci are? What picture clues tell you they are close to the park?
Grandma helped the community come together at the park. How do think the people in this community feel now? (MB)
Did you use clues from the pictures to answer our question?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What do you see that lets you know this is a city?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, use Equity Sticks to choose two or three children to share their answers.
Possible answers:
Invite children to try out different writing tools with you as they write about a favorite place in their neighborhood. Note that it could be their school.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What are the people doing at the park when Ceci visits the first time?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Words taught in the context of a story allow learners to comprehend vocabulary more easily, as does encouraging children to share their new words at home. Allow multilingual children to share translations for each word in their own languages to create a diverse classroom.

section-block.rac_body-text: Ask children about their favorite places in the neighborhood. Sing “We’ll Go For a Walk” from Day 1.
Ask children to show thumbs up if they came to school by bus. By car? By walking? Ask children to tell about what they saw on their way to school.
Introduce two new words that will be helpful to the continued conversation about rules.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to read a map called Our Neighborhood. It is an informational text that uses pictures to give us information.
Pablo loves looking at pictures because he can learn so much from them.
Ofrenda and Our Neighborhood both use pictures to show a neighborhood. Let’s see what this neighborhood looks like.
As we read the Big Chart, let’s talk about the concept question for the week:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What is it like where we live?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to Where We Live
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart, then use these prompts to read and discuss the map. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who can point to the library? What can you do there?
A post office is where you go to mail a letter. What clues helped you find the post office? Let’s read the words from left to right.
Who can point to the school bus? What building is the bus near?
Ceci and Grandma go to the park to make the ofrenda. Who can find the park on this map? What clues did you use to find it?
Ceci’s town has lots of stores and a bakery. Where is the bakery in this neighborhood? What do they sell there?
I see the letter B in the word bakery. Who can point to the letter B in the word bakery? What sound does it make?

section.rac_body-text: Ask children to imagine they live in the neighborhood shown on the map. Invite children to “ride the bus” with you around the neighborhood and sing the verses of “The Wheels on the Bus.”
Provide a writing prompt about the children’s neighborhood. Give ongoing feedback as children draw in response to the prompt. Allow time for sharing writing.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: When discussing neighborhoods, encourage discussion of the unique cultural aspects of different communities. Developing respect and appreciation for diversity early on can help prevent children from developing misconceptions about other people. This way, you raise their cognitive development levels and increase their capacity for connection.

section-block.rac_body-text: Remind children that Ceci loved her little turtle and may have sung this song to him. Invite children to join in as you use hand motions and sing “There Was a Little Turtle.”
Draw a cloud on a chart. Then add a face to make it a happy cloud. Draw more clouds and invite children to use their imaginations to create special cloud pictures. (MB)

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we’re going to reread Ofrenda by Maricruz Hernández Álvarez and illustrated by Carolina Farias. We will think about the details so we can retell and act out the story.
Pablo is excited to reread the story! He really likes it.
We’ve read the story and talked a lot about our neighborhood and Ceci’s neighborhood. Today we’re going to keep this question in mind:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How is your neighborhood like Ceci’s?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: In what ways do the people in Ceci’s neighborhood travel from place to place? One of those ways
is a taxi. Let’s hop in a taxi and ride. Let’s pay for the ride. Now, it’s time for a bus ride. Let’s pay and get on. Here we go! (MB)
Look at all the things people are doing at the park. Let’s pretend we’re in the park. Let’s have a game of catch. I’ll throw the ball and you catch it. (MB)
Grandma and Ceci go to a store to buy tissue paper. They use it make pretty figures to decorate the ofrenda. Let’s pretend we are making a figure. What would you make?
I see the letter f in the word figures. Can you point to the letter f in the word figures? What sound does the word figures begin with?

section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk about the concept question:
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How is your neighborhood like Ceci’s?
section.rac_body-text: Using Equity Sticks, choose two or three children to share their ideas.
Possible responses:
Invite children to draw and/or write about their neighborhood shops and share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What stores are in both Ceci’s neighborhood and yours?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Before children learn that groups of letters form words, they can become familiar with print concepts. These basic principles introduce children to the idea that written words have meaning. Children must understand this before they can learn any other literacy skills. As you reread the book, point out to children the page numbers and pictures. Point out that on every page you are reading left to right, from the top of the page to the bottom.
